div2.p: I hit her before she could speak. I flicked my arm out, held it the smallesst fraction of a second, then brought it down sideways as hard as I could; sure that itshe would twist her head aside. But in thethat smallest fraction of a warning second she finally decided; and decision was the savage unavoided slap knocking her sideways. Even so her hand flashed up instinctively, and her eyes blinked with shock.

We stared wildly at each other for a moment. Not in love. No name, no name, but unable to wear masks. She recovered
first. Behind her I could see people stopped on the path. A man stood up from his seat. The Indian sat and watched. Her left hand was over the side of her face, shielding it as well as soothing it. Her eyes were wet, perhaps with the pain. But she was slowly smiling. That archaic smile, her variant of theirs, steadier, braver, far less implacable, without malice or arrogance, yet still that smile.

p.del: To arrive where we started, and to know the place for the first time.

div2.p: And suddenly the truth came to me, as we stood there, trembling, searching, at our points, of fulcrum. There were no watching eyes. The windows were as blank as they looked. The theatre was empty. It was not a theatre. They had told her it was a theatre, and she believed them, and I had believed her. To bring us to this. – not for themselves, but for us . I turned and looked at the all windows.the facade, the pompous white pedimental figures, with their arses like
Then she buried her face in her hands, as if some inexorable mechanism had started.

I was so sure. It was logical, the characteristic and perfect final touchto the godgame. They had absconded. I was so sure, and yet... after so much, how could I be perfectly sure? How could they be so cold? So inhuman? So uncurious?So load the dice and yet leave the game? And if I was wasn't sure?

I gave her hebowed head one last stare, then I was walking. Firmer than Orpheus, as firm as Alison herself, that other day of parting, not once looking back. The autumn grass, the autumn sky. People. A blackbird, poor fool, singing out of season from the willows by the lake. A flight of grey pigeons over the houses. Fragments of freedom, an anagram made flesh. And somewhere the stinging smell of burning leaves.
